```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```


```{r,include=FALSE}
library(tidyverse) 
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
``` 



## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

###The Code Stuff
```{r cars}
dat <- list() #an empty list

f <- list.files(pattern=".csv") #store the file names

for(i in f){
  m <- unlist(strsplit(i,"_"))
  who <- m[1]
  rep <- gsub(".csv","",m[3])
  dat.i <- read_csv(i)%>%
    mutate(who=who,rep=rep)
  dat[[i]] <- dat.i
}
all.dat <- do.call(rbind,dat)
max.dat <- all.dat %>%
  group_by(who,rep) %>%
  summarise(max = max(cm))
  
max.dat %>%
  group_by(who)%>%
  summarise(mean.max=mean(max),sd.max=sd(max))
  se <- function(x){sd(x)/sqrt(length(x))}
  ymaxError <- function(x){mean.max + sd(x)}
  yminError <- function(x){mean.max - sd(x)}
  max.dat%>%
    group_by(who)%>%
    summarise(mean.max=mean(max),sd.max=sd(max),se.max=se(max))%>%
    ggplot(aes(x=who,y=mean.max)) + geom_point(aes(col=who)) + geom_errorbar(ymin = yminError, ymax = ymaxError)
  

```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
